text: Drink 8 Glasses of Water a Day
fact: No need to count cups. Research shows people who gulp a glass of H2O when theyâre thirsty get enough to stay healthy and hydrated. Water-rich foods like soup, fruit, and vegetables and drinks like juice, tea, and coffee all help you get your fill. You might need to drink more water if your urine is dark yellow, you donât go regularly, you're very active, or you live in a hot climate.

text: Eggs Are Bad for Your Heart
fact: Omelet lovers, rejoice. Eating an egg or two a day doesnât raise the risk of heart disease in healthy people. Yes, the yolks have cholesterol, but for most of us, the amount found in any one food isnât as bad for you as the mix of fats from everything you eat. Whatâs more, eggs have nutrients, like omega-3s, that may lower the risk of heart disease.

text: Antiperspirant Causes Breast Cancer
fact: Donât sweat it! Some scientists think the chemicals found in antiperspirants and deodorants can be absorbed through your underarm. The idea is they end up in breast tissue and make tumors more likely. But the National Cancer Institute says thereâs no evidence connecting either product with breast cancer.

text: Being Cold Gives You a Cold
fact: No matter what your grandma might've told you, spending too much time in the cold air doesnât make you sick. One study found that healthy men who spent several hours in temperatures just above freezing had an increase in healthy, virus-fighting activity in their immune systems. In fact, youâre more likely to get sick indoors, where germs are easily passed.

text: You Need a Daily Multivitamin
fact: You may have heard that a multivitamin can make up for nutrients that aren't in your diet. Researchers donât all agree on that point. But if your doctor tells you to take vitamin, do it. And if youâre pregnant, you need to take folic acid to lower the risk of birth defects. Still, the best way to get your nutrients is to eat a diet filled with fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, and healthy oils.

text: Eat Breakfast to Lose Weight
fact: Eating breakfast does help some people lose weight. It can stave off hunger, and it might prevent random eating later in the day. If youâre not a breakfast fan, you can still slim down. A Cornell University study found that the non-breakfast crowd didnât overeat at lunch and dinner, and they ate about 400 fewer calories a day. The bottom line: Skipping breakfast may help some healthy people shed pounds.

text: Green Mucus Means Infection
fact: The contents of your tissue canât take the place of a lab test. Studies show that green or yellow mucus is slightly more common in certain bacterial infections. But itâs not a sure sign that you have one or that you need antibiotics. A sinus infection can cause clear mucus, and a common cold can turn it green.

text: Sugar Makes Kids Hyper
fact: Sugar isnât good for kids, but research shows the sweet stuff wonât cause them to act out, hurt their schoolwork, or make them unable to focus. Since many parents believe thereâs a link, though, they expect their kids to behave badly after eating sugary food. So, theyâre primed to notice it if it happens.

text: A Toilet Seat Can Make You Sick
fact: Donât stress if you canât cover the seat. Toilet seats are usually pretty clean -- itâs bathroom doors, door handles, and floors that tend to be covered with bugs like E. coli, norovirus (a.k.a. âstomach fluâ), and the flu. Cover your hand with a paper towel before you touch doors or handles, and use hand sanitizer or wash afterward.

text: Cracking Joints Causes Arthritis
fact: The sound might annoy people around you, but thatâs about all the harm it does. You may think bones or joints rub together to cause the noise, but thatâs not so. It results from a gas bubble that forms between the bones and âpops.â If you enjoy doing it, keep on. Studies show it doesnât cause or play a role in arthritis. If you feel regular or severe pain when you do it, see your doctor.

text: Mental Health Myths You Need to Stop Believing in 2025
fact: by GenPsych | Mar 5, 2025 | Mental Health

text: People believe: Mental Health Myths You Need to Stop Believing in 2025
fact: by GenPsych | Mar 5, 2025 | Mental Health

text: Mental Health Myths You Need to Stop Believing in 2025
fact: Mental health is a crucial aspect of our overall well-being, yet numerous myths and misconceptions persist, due to the lack of knowledge being generated by society hindering understanding and access to proper care. These myths not only create barriers to seeking help but also contribute to misunderstandings about mental illnesses. Using the terms words like “schizo” and “psycho” which is offensive slang to be used on an Individual has perpetuated the myth that mental illness and violence go hand in hand.

text: Myths and Facts about Mental Health
fact: Despite growing awareness, these mental health myths prevent people from seeking therapy, counseling, or psychiatric treatment. At GenPsych, we believe in breaking these myths and providing accessible, high-quality mental health care for children, adolescents, and adults.

text: Our Mission
fact: Facts: Debunking this myth encourages a more compassionate understanding of mental health challenges within diverse communities. The reality is that mental health disorders do not discriminate based on age, gender, race, or socioeconomic status. They can affect anyone, regardless of their background.

text: About GenPsych
fact: Facts: Mental health issues are widespread. Approximately one in five American adults experience a mental health issue annually, and one in 20 lives with a serious mental illness such as anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, and many more mental health conditions.

text: General Inquiries
fact: Facts: Conditions like generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), major depressive disorder, and panic disorder are not phases that people can just “snap out of.” They require mental health treatment, which may include cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), medication management, and lifestyle changes.

text: Accredited By The Joint Commission
fact: Fact: Mental health care isn’t just for crises; it’s for growth you don’t have to wait until a crisis to seek help. Therapy and mental health treatment can benefit mild to moderate cases of stress, anxiety, or depression, preventing them from worsening. Mental health care is just as important as physical health care, you don’t need to be at your worst to deserve support.

fact: No matter what your grandma might've told you, spending too much time in the cold air doesnât make you sick. One study found that healthy men who spent several hours in temperatures just above freezing had an increase in healthy, virus-fighting activity in their immune systems. In fact, youâre more likely to get sick indoors, where germs are easily passed.

text: You Need a Daily Multivitamin
fact: You may have heard that a multivitamin can make up for nutrients that aren't in your diet. Researchers donât all agree on that point. But if your doctor tells you to take vitamin, do it. And if youâre pregnant, you need to take folic acid to lower the risk of birth defects. Still, the best way to get your nutrients is to eat a diet filled with fruits, vegetables, whole grains, nuts, and healthy oils.

text: Eat Breakfast to Lose Weight
fact: Eating breakfast does help some people lose weight. It can stave off hunger, and it might prevent random eating later in the day. If youâre not a breakfast fan, you can still slim down. A Cornell University study found that the non-breakfast crowd didnât overeat at lunch and dinner, and they ate about 400 fewer calories a day. The bottom line: Skipping breakfast may help some healthy people shed pounds.

text: Green Mucus Means Infection
fact: The contents of your tissue canât take the place of a lab test. Studies show that green or yellow mucus is slightly more common in certain bacterial infections. But itâs not a sure sign that you have one or that you need antibiotics. A sinus infection can cause clear mucus, and a common cold can turn it green.

text: Sugar Makes Kids Hyper
fact: Sugar isnât good for kids, but research shows the sweet stuff wonât cause them to act out, hurt their schoolwork, or make them unable to focus. Since many parents believe thereâs a link, though, they expect their kids to behave badly after eating sugary food. So, theyâre primed to notice it if it happens.

text: A Toilet Seat Can Make You Sick
fact: Donât stress if you canât cover the seat. Toilet seats are usually pretty clean -- itâs bathroom doors, door handles, and floors that tend to be covered with bugs like E. coli, norovirus (a.k.a. âstomach fluâ), and the flu. Cover your hand with a paper towel before you touch doors or handles, and use hand sanitizer or wash afterward.

text: Cracking Joints Causes Arthritis
fact: The sound might annoy people around you, but thatâs about all the harm it does. You may think bones or joints rub together to cause the noise, but thatâs not so. It results from a gas bubble that forms between the bones and âpops.â If you enjoy doing it, keep on. Studies show it doesnât cause or play a role in arthritis. If you feel regular or severe pain when you do it, see your doctor.

text: Mental Health Myths You Need to Stop Believing in 2025
fact: Mental health is a crucial aspect of our overall well-being, yet numerous myths and misconceptions persist, due to the lack of knowledge being generated by society hindering understanding and access to proper care. These myths not only create barriers to seeking help but also contribute to misunderstandings about mental illnesses. Using the terms words like “schizo” and “psycho” which is offensive slang to be used on an Individual has perpetuated the myth that mental illness and violence go hand in hand.

text: Myths and Facts about Mental Health
fact: Despite growing awareness, these mental health myths prevent people from seeking therapy, counseling, or psychiatric treatment. At GenPsych, we believe in breaking these myths and providing accessible, high-quality mental health care for children, adolescents, and adults.

text: Our Mission
fact: Facts: Debunking this myth encourages a more compassionate understanding of mental health challenges within diverse communities. The reality is that mental health disorders do not discriminate based on age, gender, race, or socioeconomic status. They can affect anyone, regardless of their background.

text: About GenPsych
fact: Facts: Mental health issues are widespread. Approximately one in five American adults experience a mental health issue annually, and one in 20 lives with a serious mental illness such as anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, and many more mental health conditions.

text: General Inquiries
fact: Facts: Conditions like generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), major depressive disorder, and panic disorder are not phases that people can just “snap out of.” They require mental health treatment, which may include cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), medication management, and lifestyle changes.

text: Accredited By The Joint Commission
fact: Fact: Mental health care isn’t just for crises; it’s for growth you don’t have to wait until a crisis to seek help. Therapy and mental health treatment can benefit mild to moderate cases of stress, anxiety, or depression, preventing them from worsening. Mental health care is just as important as physical health care, you don’t need to be at your worst to deserve support.
